snippet: Syria advised Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister to “keep his mouth closed and keep his country out of a matter that is none of his business.”

byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Vienna, David D. Kirkpatrick from London, and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations. Thomas Erdbrink contributed reporting from Tehran, and Rick Gladstone from New York.
byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER, DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and SOMINI SENGUPTA

abstract: Syrian peace talks in Vienna face enormous challenges, not least of which is getting rivals Saudi Arabia and Iran to agree on terms, as each has vested interest in outcome; Iran and Saudi Arabia are seen as actively seeking Middle East dominance and Syria has become their primary battlefield to that end.
lead_paragraph: Syria advised Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister to “keep his mouth closed and keep his country out of a matter that is none of his business.”

headline.print_headline: Rancor Between Saudi Arabia and Iran Threatens Talks on Syria
headline.main: Rancor Between Saudi Arabia and Iran Threatens Talks on Syria
